image.altText: A metal pipe bomb post-detonation laying on leaf-littered ground.

props.synopsis: ACT police say they have found four more pipe bombs in the Belconnen area, after 11 explosive devices were discovered close to Lake Ginninderra earlier in the week.

title.children: Four more pipe bombs found in Canberra as probe continues

image.altText: The exteior of a modern apartment block.

props.synopsis: Large glazed windows are a popular design flaw in Australian apartments, according to an expert.

title.children: Why apartments with floor-to-ceiling windows are a 'trade-off' in Australia

image.altText: A children's toy bear laying sideways on a floor.

props.synopsis: Documents detailing five years' worth of childcare breaches in the ACT reveal cases of educators slapping children, forcibly shaking them, throwing them, and possessing child exploitation material.

title.children: 'She was slapped': Inappropriate childcare educator discipline exposed

image.altText: A composite of luxury jewellery including rings and watches.

props.synopsis: Lawyers say the value of the allegedly stolen luxury goods, including a $5 million Richard Mille watch, is disputed as the case returns to court.

title.children: Two French men to plead guilty over alleged $10m theft in Canberra

image.altText: A colourful children's toy block lies sideways in front of a colourful abacus.

props.synopsis: Never-before-seen documents reveal reports of sexual abuse, inappropriate educator discipline, and children missing from ACT childcare centres.

title.children: Thousands of documents show behind the scenes of embattled childcare industry

image.altText: A yellow and purple car impounded by police.

props.synopsis: A major police operation at Summernats has resulted in 19 vehicle seizures, hundreds of traffic offences and multiple arrests.

title.children: Police seize 19 vehicles after dangerous driving at Summernats

image.altText: Numerous cars float in brown water between a bend in a road and a building with a green tin roof.

props.synopsis: Record-breaking rain fell on the popular holiday towns in the space of a mere few hours on Thursday, triggering flash flooding that swept away cars, caravans and tents. Here's what we know about the intense rain system.

title.children: What we know about the Great Ocean Road's unprecedented weather event

image.altText: A building shaped like round white ball surrounded by ice.

props.synopsis: Here is what we know about the US military footprint in Greenland, and how the increase of troops from Denmark and its allies stacks up.

title.children: Once top secret, Greenland's only US military base stirs trouble

image.altText: man holds cocktail class and looks to the side

props.synopsis: David Prince-Popovich registered as an official lobbyist in Tasmania despite being a convicted fraudster, against the register's rules.

title.children: 'We have no knowledge of David': Fraudster registered as lobbyist for company

image.altText: Two men in flight suits and helmets in bushland with rescue gear beside them.

props.synopsis: Jake McCollum's bluetooth headphones allowed him to receive calls through his otherwise unusable phone during the arduous wait for emergency services.

title.children: Teen survives 80m mountain fall thanks to GPS locator and headphones

image.altText: From today, under-16s will no longer have access to social media like Instagram, Facebook and TikTok.

props.synopsis: The findings of a newly released study have challenged one-size-fits-all rules and blanket bans, as the Australian government's social media ban for children under 16 has been in effect for over a month.

title.children: Australian study finds moderate social media use linked to best teen wellbeing

image.altText: A white ship sits still on the ocean at a port against a blue sky

props.synopsis: Tokyo hopes the plan to mine as much as 16 million tonnes of rare earths will help reduce its reliance on China, but will it work?

title.children: Japan wants to mine the seabed at a depth of 6 kilometres for one reason: China

image.altText: The smoke stacks of the Bayswater power station.

props.synopsis: In a move labelled a sign of the times, energy firm AGL was last week offering customers money to cut use during a heatwave.

title.children: Households 'paid to switch off' as extreme weather stalks power grid

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers has come out in support of Michele Bullock after the Reserve Bank governor signed a joint statement in solidarity with Mr Powell, who is facing criminal prosecution driven by US President Donald Trump.

title.children: Chalmers backs Bullock, global markets up on 'massive' AI chips deal — as it happened

image.altText: woman holding cheque

props.synopsis: Australian woman Laura Wells was confused to find an "official-looking letter" from the US with a $51 reimbursement, but it turns out it was legitimate.

title.children: US lawsuit results in mystery cheque from Amazon in woman's mailbox

image.altText: Maddison Inglis walking onto the court and waving to the crowd

props.synopsis: Maddison Inglis and Jason Kubler were able to celebrate their Australian Open qualifications together in a heartwarming moment.

title.children: Engaged Aussie tennis stars qualify for Open within an hour of each other

image.altText: A stone statue lies in several large pieces after being smashed on a brick and concrete floor.

props.synopsis: Residents of a north-west NSW town are angry and heartbroken after a statue with more than 100 years of history was unceremoniously shattered in the middle of the night.

title.children: Outrage after 'attack' on 100-year-old Anzac statue caught on CCTV

image.altText: Tiana Storm and Janine Hunt pose in front of a sunrise at Broadbeach.

props.synopsis: How these young people are using sunrises and sunsets to create connection, build friendships and fight the war against loneliness.

title.children: 'A place to talk': How people are using sunrises and sunsets to connect

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks stern, watching while another politican talks.

props.synopsis: A split is emerging at a state level over the government's plan to establish a national gun buyback scheme following the Bondi terror attack.

title.children: PM gears up for fight with Liberal premiers on gun buybacks

image.altText: people over a bridge

props.synopsis: Waverley Council held an extraordinary meeting last night, but the future of the footbridge used by the Bondi gunmen remains undecided.

title.children: Future of Bondi terror attack bridge on hold after locals oppose teardown

image.altText: A satellite image shows a large burnt area and smoke pouring from a fire.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of images captured by an orbiting weather satellite, and stitched together by the ABC, show the scale and destructive force of the Victorian bushfires.

title.children: Pieced-together satellite images show bushfire crisis unfolding

image.altText: A pile of tyres in a paddock is seen on fire.

props.synopsis: Dozens of firefighters worked to contain the fast-moving blaze, which burned through a paddock and a pile of tyres as it approached homes near Melton.

title.children: Smoke warning after grassfire races towards homes in outer Melbourne

image.altText: A man sitting on a boat

props.synopsis: Lawyers for Kieren Mittelheuser have applied for a registry committal for charges of accessory after the fact to murder and perverting justice.

title.children: Man charged in Pheobe Bishop case has matters mentioned in court

image.altText: Alexis Hutcheon sits on a stair well.

props.synopsis: A major Australian study finds standard antidepressants are not effective for about 20 per cent of people, who may need alternative treatments.

title.children: Antidepressants failing many people, major study reveals

image.altText: A woman holds her head in frustration while looking at a computer screen.

props.synopsis: Have you turned on your work computer after a holiday, only to find so many updates and security enhancements that you may as well take a break before you start?

title.children: Are relentless computer updates driving you crazy? You're not alone

image.altText: An old newspaper clipping photo of two men and two women raising drinks.

props.synopsis: With whisky and lollies for sustenance and pigeons their only means of communication, Steve Harris and Doug Fleming crossed Bass Strait in a 4.5m dinghy in 1974.

title.children: Two blokes, whisky and lollies on a 'foolhardy' Bass Strait crossing

image.altText: Flowering poppies are neatly fenced with a sign warning against trespassing and that illegal use of the crop may cause death.

props.synopsis: Investigations are continuing into the theft of a large quantity of poppy capsules from a Tasmanian farm. Police have confirmed the harvested area equates to 10 tennis courts, or 2,500 square metres.

title.children: 10 tennis courts' worth of poppies stolen in recent theft, police say

image.altText: Epaulette shark pictured underwater on the ocean floor

props.synopsis: Known best for their ability to "walk" on the sand and coral where they usually live, new research shows epaulette sharks could also defy assumptions in other ways.

title.children: This tiny, walking shark is doing something never seen before

image.altText: tennis player kimberly birrell smashes a forehand.

props.synopsis: It was a tough ask from the outset for Kimberly Birrell, coming up against the teen sensation Victoria Mboko who has been in excellent form of late.

title.children: Birrell knocked out of Adelaide International semifinal by Mboko

image.altText: Belle Brockhoff smiles while speaking at a media event

props.synopsis: Former snowboard cross world champion Belle Brockhoff announces her retirement just weeks out from the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics, due to a series of significant long-term injuries.

title.children: Injuries force snowboard champ Brockhoff to quit weeks before Olympics

image.altText: A python resting on a straw mat

props.synopsis: It's fair to say when a Brisbane resident woke up to discover a carpet python curled up on top of her she was rattled.

title.children: 'Babe, don't move': Woman wakes up to 2.5-metre python curled up on top of her

image.altText: A woman with her hair up in a pink suit looks directly at the camera.

props.synopsis: A growing number of women in the Northern Territory are travelling interstate to give birth — or leaving the territory altogether — following the sudden closure of the only private hospital maternity ward. Now, the NT's last private obstetrician is closing her practice.

title.children: NT's last private obstetrician walks as maternity services face collapse

image.altText: Acting Inspector Dale Maxwell

props.synopsis: Victoria Police has arrested three teenagers aged between 13 and 16 after they allegedly broke into a home, wielding machetes.

title.children: Three teens arrested following violent home invasion in Melbourne's south-east

image.altText: A close of two men running

props.synopsis: An Albany man runs roughly three marathons in laps of a hilly parkrun to raise funds for a charity that helped him through a tough time.

title.children: Twenty-four parkruns in 24 hours no sweat for WA runner
